- FY 2024/25 Budget: Frw 5,690.1 billion (11.2% increase, Frw 574.5B from revised FY 2023/24)
- Quote: "The 2024/25 budget proposal reflects Rwanda's economic resilience in face of external shocks. Government remains committed to prioritizing spending, making strategic investments to achieve NST1 objectives, and maintain economic stability."
- "Rwanda's growth momentum remains strong, despite challenging environment caused by climate change effects, global inflation, geopolitical tensions."
- Economic projections: 6.6% (2024), 6.5% (2025), 6.8% (2026), 7.2% (2027)
- Budget composition:
  - Domestic revenues: Frw 3,414.4B (tax: Frw 2,970.4B, other: Frw 444.0B)
  - External loans: Frw 1.32T
  - External grants: Frw 725.3B
- Priority areas: Agriculture, private sector development, youth employment, energy, ICT, transport, financial development, health, education, disaster management, social protection, governance, justice, reconciliation

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Strong budget growth (11.2%) despite global challenges. Consistent 6.5-7.2% GDP growth projection through 2027 shows confidence. ICT and financial development are explicitly prioritized. Youth employment focus aligns with fintech job creation goals.

#### DOCUMENT RW-POL-003
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.newtimes.co.rw/article/24042/news/economy/central-bank-governor-rwangombwa-confident-in-strong-economic-outlook
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Political/Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Governor Statement
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-02

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Governor John Rwangombwa served February 25, 2013 - February 25, 2025 (maximum 2 consecutive 6-year terms)
- Succeeded by Soraya Hakuziyaremye (February 25, 2025) - first woman BNR Governor
- November 2024: Presented Central Bank annual report (July 1, 2023 - June 30, 2024) to both chambers of Parliament
- Quote: "By next year we expect that almost all financial services interoperable whether you have MTN or Airtel code or any digital channel, you will be able to make payments as all will be interconnected."
- March 2024: Inflation expected to average ~5% in 2024
- GDP projected 6.6% (2024) after 8.2% (2023)
- Quote: "The NBR will continue to monitor emerging risks such as climate risk and cyber security, to ensure resilient financial system capable of contributing to economic development of Rwanda."
- February 2025 interview: Fintech strategy envisioned by Government to make Rwanda regional leader in financial technology through bold five-year strategy
- July 2024 BOT study: Women hold 25% board positions, 30% senior management in commercial banks
- Strategic Plan 2025-2030: Expand financial inclusion to 87% of adults

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Interoperability of all payment channels by 2026 is GAME-CHANGER. MFI software must be prepared for full mobile money integration. 87% financial inclusion target by 2030 is very ambitious. Women in leadership (25-30%) shows progress but room for improvement.

### SECTION 2: TAX & FISCAL POLICY (4 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT RW-TAX-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://rdb.rw/why-rwanda/investment-incentives/
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Investment Incentives
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-2025

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Standard CIT rate: 30% (up to 2023), reduced to 28% (from 2024)
- Zero CIT (0%) for: International companies relocating headquarters to Rwanda, philanthropic investors
- 15% preferential CIT for strategic sectors: Energy, transport, affordable housing, ICT, financial services
- 3% preferential CIT for: Pure holding companies, SPVs for investment, collective investment schemes, foreign-sourced trading income, foreign-sourced royalties of IP companies
- Seven-year tax holiday (USD 50M minimum investment, 30% equity):
  - Manufacturing, tourism, health, exports
  - Energy projects ≥25 MW (excluding EPC for government)
  - ICT with manufacturing/assembly/service
- Five-year tax holiday: Micro-finance institutions, specialized innovation park developers, specialized industrial park developers
- Accelerated depreciation: 50% flat rate first year for new/used assets
- Preferential WHT: 5% on dividends and interest for investors in companies listed on Rwanda Stock Exchange
- Angel investors (minimum USD 500K in startup): Exempt from capital gains tax and WHT for first 5 dividend issuances
- SME investors (export-focused): 150% tax deduction of qualifying internationalization expenditures
- 2024: RDB's One Stop Centre (OSC) single point for mining investors (licensing to investment incentives)
- 2024: Rwanda secured USD 3.2B in investment commitments (32.4% above target), 51,000+ jobs created

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Rwanda has the MOST GENEROUS tax incentive regime in East Africa. 0% CIT for HQ relocations is extraordinary. 15% for financial services vs 28-30% standard is significant. Five-year tax holiday specifically for MFIs is UNIQUE - no other country offers this. This makes Rwanda extremely attractive for MFI software company establishment. However, note investor complaints about RDB-RRA misalignment on incentive implementation.

#### DOCUMENT RW-TAX-004
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.state.gov/reports/2024-investment-climate-statements/rwanda
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Tax/Investment
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: US Government Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024

**KEY CONTENT**:
- US State Department 2024 Investment Climate Statements: Rwanda
- Notes: Some investors reported tax incentives/deals negotiated with RDB and line ministries interpreted differently by RRA
- Some initial tax incentive packages well-respected, but later expansion attempts faced obstacles when incentives changed or not honored
- Investors and tax practitioners observed securing tax incentives through RDB doesn't always translate into seamless application with RRA
- Misalignment between RDB and RRA can cause delays in accessing exemptions or applying approved incentive terms

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: CRITICAL WARNING - There's a known disconnect between RDB (which grants incentives) and RRA (which enforces tax). Need to get RRA confirmation in writing for any incentives, not just RDB approval. This is a significant implementation risk.

### SECTION 4: MFI SECTOR DATA (3 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT RW-DATA-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.bnr.rw/financial-stability/microfinance-institutions/list-of-licensed-mfis-and-sac/
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Regulatory List
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-12

**KEY CONTENT**:
- As of December 2024: 434 licensed Deposit-Taking Microfinance Institutions (DTMFIs)
  - 22 public limited companies
  - 412 SACCOs (including 391 Umurenge SACCOs from 2008 program - one SACCO per administrative sector)
- Depositors: ~2.3 million (nearly half of adult population)
- Deposits: RWF 481 billion (49.4% increase from previous year)
- Total assets: RWF 883 billion (39.4% growth in 2024)
- Regulation No. 57/2023 (27/03/2023): Minimum paid-up capital
  - MFI companies: RWF 1 billion
  - Cooperatives: RWF 100 million
  - Transitional: Existing institutions have up to 5 years to comply
- Capital adequacy: 32.3% (well above 15% minimum)
- Notable licensed MFIs: Urwego Bank (1997, World Relief, transitioned to deposit-taking 2024), Duterimbere IMF PLC (2004, women entrepreneurs focus), AB Bank, Zigama, Unguka
- 16 commercial banks + numerous MFIs + rural savings and credit cooperatives

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: 434 licensed DTMFIs is the LARGEST number in East Africa (Kenya: 357 SACCOs + 14 MFBs, Tanzania: 1,044 SACCOs + 4 MFBs, Uganda: 3 MDIs). Rwanda's MFI sector is massive and growing (49.4% deposit growth, 39.4% asset growth). 391 Umurenge SACCOs created by government program shows state-led financial inclusion. 2.3M depositors = nearly 50% of adults is exceptional penetration. RWF 481B deposits, RWF 883B assets is substantial. Minimum capital requirements (RWF 1B for companies, RWF 100M for cooperatives) will drive consolidation over 5-year transition period.

#### DOCUMENT RW-DATA-002
**SOURCE_URL**: https://allafrica.com/stories/202510020490.html
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Analysis
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-10

**KEY CONTENT**:
- FinScope Survey 2024: SACCO membership fell to 28% of adults (~2.3M people) from 36% (~2.5M) in 2020
- Overall financial inclusion: 96% of Rwandan adults
- Formal financial inclusion: 77% (2020) → 92% (2024)
- Mobile money usage: 86% of adults have used, 77% have registered mobile wallet (~6.9M people)
- All 416 Umurenge SACCOs automated by June 2024
- Consolidation to 30 District SACCOs underway (each Umurenge SACCO becomes branch of District SACCO)
- Nearly half of SACCO members are farmers (mostly rural) - groups banks neglect

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: PARADOX - Overall financial inclusion up to 96% (excellent) but SACCO membership DOWN from 36% to 28%. This is mobile money substitution effect. 86% have used mobile money, 77% have wallet - mobile money is DOMINANT. Umurenge SACCO automation complete June 2024 is very recent. Consolidation from 416 to 30 District SACCOs is MASSIVE change - from micro-local to district-level. This creates opportunity for enterprise software (district level needs sophisticated systems) but threat to Umurenge-level vendors. Farmers = 50% of SACCO members but underserved by banks - agri-lending opportunity.
